content.description:
Sit start below the prodding fin of rock.

Climb up the fin with a couple of steep moves at the start, which isn't all that bad if you know the numbers.

Traverse of to the left with care.

'Action Figure' start into 'Cholos'.  Doesn't feel too bad once you have 'Cholos' sussed out.  Although not the nicest line, this problem is historically significant because it was the second double digit problem at the Happies and one of only a handful in Bishop at the time.

Sit start on pockets or a large fin-like hold about 10 feet to the right of the "Action figure" start. Pull on the wall and make a few hard pocket pulls before heading up through the hole between the boulder and the wall behind with a huge powerful jump move to a mega-bucket pocket jug. Don't dab and fully commit to this move, or perhaps a spinal injury could occur. A fun line slightly spoiled by its location.
content.location: In the small corridor just right of "Action Figure". This problem has the same start as "Action Jackson".

content.description:
If you've got "Action Figure" figured out, this is a good link-up for those who are looking for some hard pulling on an overhang.

Sit start as for "Cholos" and use some tricky beta in order to get into the underclings and crimps of "Action Figure". Adds some pump and makes the crux of the V6 much harder!
content.location: Locate the Action Figure Alcove and sit-start about eight feet left of the jug underclings used for the start of "Action Figure". Same start as for "Cholos".

content.description: Start on pockets and climb out the black streak.  You can top it out, but I don't recommend it.  One of the original testpieces at the Happies.

Sit start about 10 feet right of Action Figure near a good flake / pockets. Traverse left and climb into Action Figure.

Good moves on small pockets.

The original line on the wall.  Used to be harder (or at least more painful) 'till someone filed out the bottom of the mono after it had already been done...

Nonetheless, great pulls on steep pockets.  Can be topped out, but not as fun as stepping off.
